docTitle.titlePart: ANNAJANSKA , THE BOLSHEVIK EMPRESS By George Bernard Shaw

front.performance: ANNAJANSKA is frankly a bravura piece . The modern variety theatre demands for its “ turns ” little plays called sketches , to last twenty minutes or so , and to enable some favorite performer to make a brief but dazzling appearance on some barely passable dramatic pretext . Miss Lillah McCarthy and I , as author and actress , have helped to make one another famous on many serious occasions , from Man and Superman to Androcles ; and Mr Charles Ricketts has not disdained to snatch moments from his painting and sculpture to design some wonderful dresses for us . We three unbent as Mrs Siddons , Sir Joshua Reynolds and Dr Johnson might have unbent , to devise a turn for the Coliseum variety theatre . Not that we would set down the art of the variety theatre as something to be condescended to , or our own art as elephantine . We should rather crave indulgence as three novices fresh from the awful legitimacy of the highbrow theatre .

titlePage.docImprint: Well , Miss McCarthy and Mr Ricketts justified themselves easily in the glamor of the footlights , to the strains of Tchaikovsky 's1812. I fear I did not . I have received only one compliment on my share ; and that was from a friend who said , “ It is the only one of your works that is not too long . ” So I have made it a page or two longer , according to my own precept : EMBRACE YOUR REPROACHES : THEY ARE OFTEN GLORIES IN DISGUISE . Annajanska was first performed at the Coliseum Theatre inLondonon the 21st January ,1918, with Lillah McCarthy as the Grand Duchess , Henry Miller as Schneidekind , and Randle Ayrton as General Strammfest .

stage.stage: The General 's office in a military station on the east front in Beotia . An office table with a telephone , writing materials , official papers , etc ., is set across the room . At the end of the table , a comfortable chair for the General . Behind the chair , a window . Facing it at the other end of the table , a plain wooden bench . At the side of the table , with its back to the door , a common chair , with a typewriter before it . Beside the door , which is opposite the end of the bench , a rack for caps and coats . There is nobody in the room .
General Strammfest enters , followed by Lieutenant Schneidekind . They hang up their cloaks and caps . Schneidekind takes a little longer than Strammfest , who comes to the table .

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: Schneidekind .

sp.speaker: SCHNEIDEKIND
sp.p: Yes , sir .

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: Have you sent my report yet to the government ?He sits down .

sp.speaker: SCHNEIDEKIND
sp.p: coming to the tableNot yet , sir . Which government do you wish it sent to ?He sits down .

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: That depends . What 's the latest ? Which of them do you think is most likely to be in power tomorrow morning ?

sp.speaker: SCHNEIDEKIND
sp.p: Well , the provisional government was going strong yesterday . But today they say that the Prime Minister has shot himself , and that the extreme left fellow has shot all the others .

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: Yes : that 's all very well ; but these fellows always shoot themselves with blank cartridge .

sp.speaker: SCHNEIDEKIND
sp.p: Still , even the blank cartridge means backing down . I should send the report to the Maximilianists .

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: They 're no stronger than the Oppidoshavians ; and in my own opinion the Moderate Red Revolutionaries are as likely to come out on top as either of them .

sp.speaker: SCHNEIDEKIND
sp.p: I can easily put a few carbon sheets in the typewriter and send a copy each to the lot .

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: Waste of paper . You might as well send reports to an infant school .He throws his head on the table with a groan .

sp.speaker: SCHNEIDEKIND
sp.p: Tired out , Sir ?

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: O Schneidekind , Schneidekind , how can you bear to live ?

sp.speaker: SCHNEIDEKIND
sp.p: At my age , sir , I ask myself how can I bear to die ?

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: You are young , young and heartless . You are excited by the revolution : you are attached to abstract things like liberty . But my family has served the Panjandrums of Beotia faithfully for seven centuries . The Panjandrums have kept our place for us at their courts , honored us , promoted us , shed their glory on us , made us what we are . When I hear you young men declaring that you are fighting for civilization , for democracy , for the overthrow of militarism , I ask myself how can a man shed his blood for empty words used by vulgar tradesmen and common laborers : mere wind and stink .He rises , exalted by his theme .A king is a splendid reality , a man raised above us like a god . You can see him ; you can kiss his hand ; you can be cheered by his smile and terrified by his frown . I would have died for my Panjandrum as my father died for his father . Your toiling millions were only too honored to receive the toes of our boots in the proper spot for them when they displeased their betters . And now what is left in life for me ?He relapses into his chair discouraged .My Panjandrum is deposed and transported to herd with convicts . The army , his pride and glory , is paraded to hear seditious speeches from penniless rebels , with the colonel actually forced to take the chair and introduce the speaker . I myself am made Commander-in-Chief by my own solicitor : a Jew , Schneidekind ! a Hebrew Jew ! It seems only yesterday that these things would have been the ravings of a madman : today they are the commonplaces of the gutter press . I live now for three objects only : to defeat the enemy , to restore the Panjandrum , and to hang my solicitor .

sp.speaker: SCHNEIDEKIND
sp.p: Be careful , sir : these are dangerous views to utter nowadays . What if I were to betray you ?

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: What !

sp.speaker: SCHNEIDEKIND
sp.p: I wo n't , of course : my own father goes on just like that ; but suppose I did ?

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: chucklingI should accuse you of treason to the Revolution , my lad ; and they would immediately shoot you , unless you cried and asked to see your mother before you died , when they would probably change their minds and make you a brigadier . Enough .He rises and expands his chest .I feel the better for letting myself go . To business .He takes up a telegram : opens it : and is thunderstruck by its contents .Great heaven !He collapses into his chair .This is the worst blow of all .

sp.speaker: SCHNEIDEKIND
sp.p: What has happened ? Are we beaten ?

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: Man , do you think that a mere defeat could strike me down as this news does : I , who have been defeated thirteen times since the war began ? O , my master , my master , my Panjandrum !he is convulsed with sobs .

sp.speaker: SCHNEIDEKIND
sp.p: They have killed him ?

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: A dagger has been struck through his heart —

sp.speaker: SCHNEIDEKIND
sp.p: Good God !

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: — and through mine , through mine .

sp.speaker: SCHNEIDEKIND
sp.p: relievedOh , a metaphorical dagger ! I thought you meant a real one . What has happened ?

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: His daughter the Grand Duchess Annajanska , she whom the Panjandrina loved beyond all her other children , has — has —he cannot finish .

sp.speaker: SCHNEIDEKIND
sp.p: Committed suicide ?

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: No . Better if she had . Oh , far far better .

sp.speaker: SCHNEIDEKIND
sp.p: in hushed tonesLeft the Church ?

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: shockedCertainly not . Do not blaspheme , young man .

sp.speaker: SCHNEIDEKIND
sp.p: Asked for the vote ?

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: I would have given it to her with both hands to save her from this .

sp.speaker: SCHNEIDEKIND
sp.p: Save her from what ? Dash it , sir , out with it .

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: She has joined the Revolution .

sp.speaker: SCHNEIDEKIND
sp.p: But so have you , sir . We 've all joined the Revolution . She does n't mean it any more than we do .

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: Heaven grant you may be right ! But that is not the worst . She had eloped with a young officer . Eloped , Schneidekind , eloped !

sp.speaker: SCHNEIDEKIND
sp.p: not particularly impressedYes , Sir .

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: Annajanska , the beautiful , the innocent , my master 's daughter !He buries his face in his hands .The telephone rings .

sp.speaker: SCHNEIDEKIND
sp.p: taking the receiverYes : G. H. Q . Yes ... Do n't bawl : I 'm not a general . Who is it speaking ?... Why did n't you say so ? do n't you know your duty ? Next time you will lose your stripe ... Oh , they 've made you a colonel , have they ? Well , they 've made me a field-marshal : now what have you to say ?... Look here : what did you ring up for ? I can n't spend the day here listening to your cheek ... What ! the Grand DuchessStrammfest starts .Where did you catch her ?

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: snatching the telephone and listening for the answerSpeak louder , will you : I am a General I know that , you dolt . Have you captured the officer that was with her ?... Damnation ! You shall answer for this : you let him go : he bribed you . You must have seen him : the fellow is in the full dress court uniform of the Panderobajensky Hussars . I give you twelve hours to catch him or ... what 's that you say about the devil ? Are you swearing at me , you ... Thousand thunders !To Schneidekind .The swine says that the Grand Duchess is a devil incarnate .Into the telephone .Filthy traitor : is that the way you dare speak of the daughter of our anointed Panjandrum ? I 'll —

sp.speaker: SCHNEIDEKIND
sp.p: pulling the telephone from his lipsTake care , sir .

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: I wo n't take care : I 'll have him shot . Let go that telephone .

sp.speaker: SCHNEIDEKIND
sp.p: But for her own sake , sir —

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: Eh ?—

sp.speaker: SCHNEIDEKIND
sp.p: For her own sake they had better send her here . She will be safe in your hands .

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: yielding the receiverYou are right . Be civil to him . I should chokehe sits down

sp.speaker: SCHNEIDEKIND
sp.p: into the telephoneHullo . Never mind all that : it 's only a fellow here who has been fooling with the telephone . I had to leave the room for a moment . Wash out : and send the girl along . We 'll jolly soon teach her to behave herself here ... Oh , you 've sent her already . Then why the devil did n't you say so , you —he hangs up the telephone angrilyJust fancy : they started her off this morning : and all this is because the fellow likes to get on the telephone and hear himself talk now that he is a colonel .The telephone rings again . He snatches the receiver furiously .What 's the matter now ?...To the General .It 's our own people downstairs .Into the receiver .Here ! do you suppose I 've nothing else to do than to hang on to the telephone all day ?... What 's that ? Not men enough to hold her ! What do you mean ?To the General .She is there , sir .

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: Tell them to send her up . I shall have to receive her without even rising , without kissing her hand , to keep up appearances before the escort . It will break my heart .

sp.speaker: SCHNEIDEKIND
sp.p: into the receiverSend her up ... Tcha !He hangs up the receiver .He says she is halfway up already : they could n't hold her . The Grand Duchess bursts into the room , dragging with her two exhausted soldiers hanging on desperately to her arms . She is enveloped from head to foot by a fur-lined cloak , and wears a fur cap .

sp.speaker: SCHNEIDEKIND
sp.p: pointing to the benchAt the word Go , place your prisoner on the bench in a sitting posture ; and take your seats right and left of her . Go . The two soldiers make a supreme effort to force her to sit down . She flings them back so that they are forced to sit on the bench to save themselves from falling backwards over it , and is herself dragged into sitting between them . The second soldier , holding on tight to the Grand Duchess with one hand , produces papers with the other , and waves them towards Schneidekind , who takes them from him and passes them on to the General . He opens them and reads them with a grave expression .

sp.speaker: SCHNEIDEKIND
sp.p: Be good enough to wait , prisoner , until the General has read the papers on your case .

sp.speaker: THE GRAND DUCHESS
sp.p: to the soldiersLet go .To StrammfestTell them to let go , or I 'll upset the bench backwards and bash our three heads on the floor .

sp.speaker: FIRST SOLDIER
sp.p: No , little mother . Have mercy on the poor .

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: growling over the edge of the paper he is readingHold your tongue .

sp.speaker: THE GRAND DUCHESS
sp.p: blazingMe , or the soldier ?

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: horrifiedThe soldier , madam .

sp.speaker: THE GRAND DUCHESS
sp.p: Tell him to let go .

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: Release the lady . The soldiers take their hands off her . One of them wipes his fevered brow . The other sucks his wrist .

sp.speaker: SCHNEIDKIND
sp.p: fiercely‘ ttention ! The two soldiers sit up stiffly .

sp.speaker: THE GRAND DUCHESS
sp.p: Oh , let the poor man suck his wrist . It may be poisoned . I bit it .

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: shockedYou bit a common soldier !

sp.speaker: GRAND DUCHESS
sp.p: Well , I offered to cauterize it with the poker in the office stove . But he was afraid . What more could I do ?

sp.speaker: SCHNEIDEKIND
sp.p: Why did you bite him , prisoner ?

sp.speaker: THE GRAND DUCHESS
sp.p: He would not let go .

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: Did he let go when you bit him ?

sp.speaker: THE GRAND DUCHESS
sp.p: No .Patting the soldier on the backYou should give the man a cross for his devotion . I could not go on eating him ; so I brought him along with me .

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: Prisoner —

sp.speaker: THE GRAND DUCHESS
sp.p: Do n't call me prisoner , General Strammfest . My grandmother dandled you on her knee .

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: bursting into tearsO God , yes . Believe me , my heart is what it was then .

sp.speaker: THE GRAND DUCHESS
sp.p: Your brain also is what it was then . I will not be addressed by you as prisoner .

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: I may not , for your own sake , call you by your rightful and most sacred titles . What am I to call you ?

sp.speaker: THE GRAND DUCHESS
sp.p: The Revolution has made us comrades . Call me comrade .

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: I had rather die .

lg.l: Then call me Annajanska ; and I will call you Peter

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: painfully agitatedSchneidekind , you must speak to her : I cannot —he breaks down .

sp.speaker: SCHNEIDEKIND
sp.p: officiallyThe Republic of Beotia has been compelled to confine the Panjandrum and his family , for their own safety , within certain bounds . You have broken those bounds .

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: taking the word from himYou are I must say it — a prisoner . What am I to do with you ?

sp.speaker: THE GRAND DUCHESS
sp.p: You should have thought of that before you arrested me .

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: Come , come , prisoner ! do you know what will happen to you if you compel me to take a sterner tone with you ?

sp.speaker: THE GRAND DUCHESS
sp.p: No . But I know what will happen to you .

sp.speaker: STRAMAIFEST
sp.p: Pray what , prisoner ?

sp.speaker: THE GLAND DUCHESS
sp.p: Clergyman 's sore throat . Schneidekind splutters ; drops a paper : and conceals his laughter under the table .

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: thunderouslyLieutenant Schneidekind .

sp.speaker: SCHNEIDEKIND
sp.p: in a stifled voiceYes , Sir .The table vibrates visibly .

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: Come out of it , you fool : you 're upsetting the ink . Schneidekind emerges , red in the face with suppressed mirth .

lg.l: Why do n't you laugh ? Do n't you appreciate Her Imperial

sp.speaker: SCHNEIDEKIND
sp.p: suddenly becoming solemnI do n't want to , sir .

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: Laugh at once , sir . I order you to laugh .

sp.speaker: SCHNEIDEKIND
sp.p: with a touch of temperI really can n't , sir .He sits down decisively .

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: growling at himYah !He turns impressively to the Grand Duchess .Your Imperial Highness desires me to address you as comrade ?

sp.speaker: THE GRAND DUCHESS
sp.p: rising and waving a red handkerchiefLong live the Revolution , comrade !

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: rising and salutingProletarians of all lands , unite . Lieutenant Schneidekind , you will rise and sing the Marseillaise .

sp.speaker: SCHNEIDEKIND
sp.p: risingBut I cannot , sir . I have no voice , no ear .

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: Then sit down ; and bury your shame in your typewriter .Schneidekind sits down .Comrade Annajanska , you have eloped with a young officer .

sp.speaker: THE GRAND DUCHESS
sp.p: astoundedGeneral Strammfest , you lie .

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: Denial , comrade , is useless . It is through that officer that your movements have been traced .The Grand Duchess is suddenly enlightened , and seems amused . Strammfest continues an a forensic manner .He joined you at the Golden Anchor in Hakonsburg . You gave us the slip there ; but the officer was traced to Potterdam , where you rejoined him and went alone to Premsylople . What have you done with that unhappy young man ? Where is he ?

sp.speaker: THE GRAND DUCHESS
sp.p: pretending to whisper an important secretWhere he has always been .

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: eagerlyWhere is that ?

sp.speaker: THE GRAND DUCHESS
sp.p: impetuouslyIn your imagination . I came alone . I am alone . Hundreds of officers travel every day from Hakonsburg to Potterdam . What do I know about them ?

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: They travel in khaki . They do not travel in full dress court uniform as this man did .

sp.speaker: SCHNEIDEKIND
sp.p: Only officers who are eloping with grand duchesses wear court uniform : otherwise the grand duchesses could not be seen with them .

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: Hold your tongue .Schneidekind , in high dudgeon , folds his arms and retires from the conversation . The General returns to his paper and to his examination of the Grand Duchess .This officer travelled with your passport . What have you to say to that ?

sp.speaker: THE GRAND DUCHESS
sp.p: Bosh ! How could a man travel with a woman 's passport ?

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: It is quite simple , as you very well know . A dozen travellers arrive at the boundary . The official collects their passports . He counts twelve persons ; then counts the passports . If there are twelve , he is satisfied .

sp.speaker: THE GRAND DUCHESS
sp.p: Then how do you know that one of the passports was mine ?

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: A waiter at the Potterdam Hotel looked at the officer 's passport when he was in his bath . It was your passport .

sp.speaker: THE GRAND DUCHESS
sp.p: Stuff ! Why did he not have me arrested ?

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: When the waiter returned to the hotel with the police the officer had vanished ; and you were there with your own passport . They knouted him .

sp.speaker: THE GRAND DUCHESS
sp.p: Oh ! Strammfest , send these men away . I must speak to you alone .

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: rising in horrorNo : this is the last straw : I cannot consent . It is impossible , utterly , eternally impossible , that a daughter of the Imperial House should speak to any one alone , were it even her own husband .

sp.speaker: THE GRAND DUCHESS
sp.p: You forget that there is an exception . She may speak to a child alone .She rises .Strammfest , you have been dandled on my grandmother 's knee . By that gracious action the dowager Panjandrina made you a child forever . So did Nature , by the way . I order you to speak to me alone . Do you hear ? I order you . For seven hundred years no member of your family has ever disobeyed an order from a member of mine . Will you disobey me ?

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: There is an alternative to obedience . The dead cannot disobey .He takes out his pistol and places the muzzle against his temple .

sp.speaker: SCHNEIDEKIND
sp.p: snatching the pistol from himFor God 's sake , General —

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: attacking him furiously to recover the weaponDog of a subaltern , restore that pistol and my honor .

sp.speaker: SCHNEIDEKIND
sp.p: reaching out with the pistol to the Grand DuchessTake it : quick : he is as strong as a bull .

sp.speaker: THE GRAND DUCHESS
sp.p: snatching itAha ! Leave the room , all of you except the General . At the double ! lightning ! electricity !She fires shot after shot , spattering the bullets about the ankles of the soldiers . They fly precipitately . She turns to Schneidekind , who has by this time been flung on the floor by the General .You too .He scrambles up .March .He flies to the door .

sp.speaker: SCHNEIDEKIND
sp.p: turning at the doorFor your own sake , comrade —

sp.speaker: THE GRAND DUCHESS
sp.p: indignantlyComrade ! You !!! Go .She fires two more shots . He vanishes .

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: making an impulsive movement towards herMy Imperial Mistress —

sp.speaker: THE GRAND DUCHESS
sp.p: Stop . I have one bullet left , if you attempt to take this from meputting the pistol to her temple

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: recoiling , and covering his eyes with his handsNo no : put it down : put it down . I promise everything : I swear anything ; but put it down , I implore you .

sp.speaker: THE GRAND DUCHESS
sp.p: throwing it on the tableThere !

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: uncovering his eyesThank God !

sp.speaker: THE GRAND DUCHESS
sp.p: gentlyStrammfest : I am your comrade . Am I nothing more to you ?

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: falling on his kneeYou are , God help me , all that is left to me of the only power I recognize on earthhe kisses her hand

sp.speaker: THE GRAND DUCHESS
sp.p: indulgentlyIdolater ! When will you learn that our strength has never been in ourselves , but in your illusions about us ?She shakes off her kindliness , and sits down in his chair .Now tell me , what are your orders ? And do you mean to obey them ?

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: starting like a goaded ox , and blundering fretfully about the roomHow can I obey six different dictators , and not one gentleman among the lot of them ? One of them orders me to make peace with the foreign enemy . Another orders me to offer all the neutral countries 48 hours to choose between adopting his views on the single tax and being instantly invaded and annihilated . A third orders me to go to a damned Socialist Conference and explain that Beotia will allow no annexations and no indemnities , and merely wishes to establish the Kingdom of Heaven on Earth throughout the universe .He finishes behind Schneidekind 's chair .

sp.speaker: THE GRAND DUCHESS
sp.p: Damn their trifling !

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: I thank Your Imperial Highness from the bottom of my heart for that expression . Europe thanks you .

sp.speaker: THE GRAND DUCHESS
sp.p: M'yes ; but —risingStrammfest , you know that your cause — the cause of the dynasty — is lost .

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: You must not say so . It is treason , even from you .He sinks , discouraged , into the chair , and covers his face with his hand .

sp.speaker: THE GRAND DUCHESS
sp.p: Do not deceive yourself , General : never again will a Panjandrum reign in Beotia .She walks slowly across the room , brooding bitterly , and thinking aloud .We are so decayed , so out of date , so feeble , so wicked in our own despite , that we have come at last to will our own destruction .

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: You are uttering blasphemy .

sp.speaker: THE GRAND DUCHESS
sp.p: All great truths begin as blasphemies . All the king 's horses and all the king 's men cannot set up my father 's throne again . If they could , you would have done it , would you not ?

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: God knows I would !

sp.speaker: THE GRAND DUCHESS
sp.p: You really mean that ? You would keep the people in their hopeless squalid misery ? you would fill those infamous prisons again with the noblest spirits in the land ? you would thrust the rising sun of liberty back into the sea of blood from which it has risen ? And all because there was in the middle of the dirt and ugliness and horror a little patch of court splendor in which you could stand with a few orders on your uniform , and yawn day after day and night after night in unspeakable boredom until your grave yawned wider still , and you fell into it because you had nothing better to do . How can you be so stupid , so heartless ?

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: You must be mad to think of royalty in such a way . I never yawned at court . The dogs yawned ; but that was because they were dogs : they had no imagination , no ideals , no sense of honor and dignity to sustain them .

sp.speaker: THE GRAND DUCHESS
sp.p: My poor Strammfest : you were not often enough at court to tire of it . You were mostly soldiering ; and when you came home to have a new order pinned on your breast , your happiness came through looking at my father and mother and at me , and adoring us . Was that not so ?

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: Do YOU reproach me with it ? I am not ashamed of it .

sp.speaker: THE GRAND DUCHESS
sp.p: Oh , it was all very well for you , Strammfest . But think of me , of me ! standing there for you to gape at , and knowing that I was no goddess , but only a girl like any other girl ! It was cruelty to animals : you could have stuck up a wax doll or a golden calf to worship ; it would not have been bored .

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: Stop ; or I shall renounce my allegiance to you . I have had women flogged for such seditious chatter as this .

sp.speaker: THE GRAND DUCHESS
sp.p: Do not provoke me to send a bullet through your head for reminding me of it .

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: You always had low tastes . You are no true daughter of the Panjandrums : you are a changeling , thrust into the Panjandrina 's bed by some profligate nurse . I have heard stories of your childhood : of how —

sp.speaker: THE GRAND DUCHESS
sp.p: Ha , ha ! Yes : they took me to the circus when I was a child . It was my first moment of happiness , my first glimpse of heaven . I ran away and joined the troupe . They caught me and dragged me back to my gilded cage ; but I had tasted freedom ; and they never could make me forget it .

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: Freedom ! To be the slave of an acrobat ! to be exhibited to the public ! to —

sp.speaker: THE GRAND DUCHESS
sp.p: Oh , I was trained to that . I had learnt that part of the business at court .

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: You had not been taught to strip yourself half naked and turn head over heels —

sp.speaker: THE GRAND DUCHESS
sp.p: Man , I WANTED to get rid of my swaddling clothes and turn head over heels . I wanted to , I wanted to , I wanted to . I can do it still . Shall I do it now ?

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: If you do , I swear I will throw myself from the window so that I may meet your parents in heaven without having my medals torn from my breast by them .

sp.speaker: THE GRAND DUCHESS
sp.p: Oh , you are incorrigible . You are mad , infatuated . You will not believe that we royal divinities are mere common flesh and blood even when we step down from our pedestals and tell you ourselves what a fool you are . I will argue no more with you : I will use my power . At a word from me your men will turn against you : already half of them do not salute you ; and you dare not punish them : you have to pretend not to notice it .

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: It is not for you to taunt me with that if it is so .

sp.speaker: THE GRAND DUCHESS
sp.p: haughtilyTaunt ! I condescend to taunt ! To taunt a common General ! You forget yourself , sir .

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: dropping on his knee submissivelyNow at last you speak like your royal self .

sp.speaker: THE GRAND DUCHESS
sp.p: Oh , Strammfest , Strammfest , they have driven your slavery into your very bones . Why did you not spit in my face ?

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: rising with a shudderGod forbid !

sp.speaker: THE GRAND DUCHESS
sp.p: Well , since you will be my slave , take your orders from me . I have not come here to save our wretched family and our bloodstained crown . I am come to save the Revolution .

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: Stupid as I am , I have come to think that I had better save that than save nothing . But what will the Revolution do for the people ? Do not be deceived by the fine speeches of the revolutionary leaders and the pamphlets of the revolutionary writers . How much liberty is there where they have gained the upper hand ? Are they not hanging , shooting , imprisoning as much as ever we did ? Do they ever tell the people the truth ? No : if the truth does not suit them they spread lies instead , and make it a crime to tell the truth .

sp.speaker: THE GRAND DUCHESS
sp.p: Of course they do . Why should they not ?

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: hardly able to believe his earsWhy should they not ?

sp.speaker: THE GRAND DUCHESS
sp.p: Yes : why should they not ? We did it . You did it , whip in hand : you flogged women for teaching children to read .

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: To read sedition . To read Karl Marx .

sp.speaker: THE GRAND DUCHESS
sp.p: Pshaw ! How could they learn to read the Bible without learning to read Karl Marx ? Why do you not stand to your guns and justify what you did , instead of making silly excuses ? Do you suppose I think flogging a woman worse than flogging a man ? I , who am a woman myself !

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: I am at a loss to understand your Imperial Highness . You seem to me to contradict yourself .

sp.speaker: THE GRAND DUCHESS
sp.p: Nonsense ! I say that if the people cannot govern themselves , they must be governed by somebody . If they will not do their duty without being half forced and half humbugged , somebody must force them and humbug them . Some energetic and capable minority must always be in power . Well , I am on the side of the energetic minority whose principles I agree with . The Revolution is as cruel as we were ; but its aims are my aims . Therefore I stand for the Revolution .

lg.l: You do not know what you are saying . This is pure
Bolshevism . Are you , the daughter of a Panjandrum , a Bolshevist ?

sp.speaker: THE GRAND DUCHESS
sp.p: I am anything that will make the world less like a prison and more like a circus .

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: Ah ! You still want to be a circus star .

sp.speaker: THE GRAND DUCHESS
sp.p: Yes , and be billed as the Bolshevik Empress . Nothing shall stop me . You have your orders , General Strammfest : save the Revolution .

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: What Revolution ? Which Revolution ? No two of your rabble of revolutionists mean the same thing by the Revolution What can save a mob in which every man is rushing in a different direction ?

sp.speaker: THE GRAND DUCHESS
sp.p: I will tell you . The war can save it .

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: The war ?

sp.speaker: THE GRAND DUCHESS
sp.p: Yes , the war . Only a great common danger and a great common duty can unite us and weld these wrangling factions into a solid commonwealth .

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: Bravo ! War sets everything right : I have always said so . But what is a united people without a united army ? And what can I do ? I am only a soldier . I cannot make speeches : I have won no victories : they will not rally to my callagain he sinks into his chair with his former gesture of discouragement

sp.speaker: THE GRAND DUCHESS
sp.p: Are you sure they will not rally to mine ?

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: Oh , if only you were a man and a soldier !

sp.speaker: THE GRAND DUCHESS
sp.p: Suppose I find you a man and a soldier ?

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: rising in a furyAh ! the scoundrel you eloped with ! You think you will shove this fellow into an army command , over my head . Never .

sp.speaker: THE GRAND DUCHESS
sp.p: You promised everything . You swore anything .She marches as if in front of a regiment .I know that this man alone can rouse the army to enthusiasm .

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: Delusion ! Folly ! He is some circus acrobat ; and you are in love with him .

sp.speaker: THE GRAND DUCHESS
sp.p: I swear I am not in love with him . I swear I will never marry him .

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: Then who is he ?

sp.speaker: THE GRAND DUCHESS
sp.p: Anybody in the world but you would have guessed long ago . He is under your very eyes .

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: staring past her right and leftWhere ?

sp.speaker: THE GRAND DUCHESS
sp.p: Look out of the window . He rushes to the window , looking for the officer . The Grand Duchess takes off her cloak and appears in the uniform of the Panderobajensky Hussars .

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: peering through the windowWhere is he ? I can see no one .

sp.speaker: THE GRAND DUCHESS
sp.p: Here , silly .

sp.speaker: STRAMMFEST
sp.p: turningYou ! Great Heavens ! The Bolshevik Empress !
